1125008193636061186.text: But we are overaccounting here, creating systems where a vast amount of the expenditure making a drug, is in pushing doctors to use innovative drugs.  That's not entirely illegitimate, but the prices are creating an entire industry that pushes doctors *not* to use those drugs.

1125008187214589952.text: There are other ways to make sure those who invent and develop safe and effective pharmaceuticals, are still rewarded for their productive work, and even protected from the costs of failed attempts that were legitimate to explore.  Innovation doesn't always work.

1125008185142571009.text:
This is a failure mode of *the economic model*.  That doesn't mean I'm not a capitalist.  I've started companies, that solve problems.  I like solving problems, I like working systems.

Your mother is no longer with us, over pennies.  Problem not solved, system not working.

1125008181892009984.text:
But in real ways, there aren't more drugs, because these accounting fictions force the entire system to avoid pharmaceutical innovation unless the gains are overwhelming.

Or in other words, health is *already* failing expensively,the pricey drug is cheaper *relative* to nothing.

1125008179048271872.text: There is a fear -- and it's *not* false -- that if pharmaceutical companies lost billions every time they made a drug, just because it ended up cheap to synthesize (usually, not always the case), well, there would be no more drugs.

1124996977018560512.text:
Coda:  It's possible you are in an unkind place, that does work according to these rules.  You get to leave, they get to fail, you will probably learn, they will possibly not.  Be kind to yourself too.

That's probably the second most important thing I've learned.

1124996971297566720.text:
I don't know if this will help anyone, but it's the most important thing I've realized.

You do not have to be perfect.  You won't be.  You get to fail.  You get to learn.  Most success comes from this learning.

People you love don't know this.  It is a kind truth to share.

1124996966918836224.text:
If you want somebody to invest in you, don't just show them your success.

Show them your growth.  The most impressive people in my life are not those who "have the knack".  They're the ones that didn't, and then did, or didn't, and hired someone who did.  I've seen both. TALENT.

1124996963584233472.text: You get to fail.  If you commit yourself to sufficiently incompatible goals, you absolutely will fail.  But guess what:  Even that guaranteed failure, is OK.  You get that failure too.  You won't be exiled, cast out, you are the weakest link, goodbye.  You failed, now you learn.

1124996951425015814.text:
There is a *tremendous* survivorship bias, then, in what anyone talks about.  Even me.  Maybe especially.

But I don't try to do completely incompatible things.  Working organizations blend the talents of many personality types.  I did tech.  Others did strategy, ops, and legal.

1124996947352248320.text: I *am* somebody who tries to learn a lot of things in a lot of fields, so don't think I don't know the space.  The only way I can navigate it is by accepting my imperfect knowledge.  Failure is built into the model.  I "ghost bust" my discoveries, and *often* find them flawed.

1124996944592375808.text:
Thinking you have to be good at everything means you see people with skills you lack, as somebody who you must learn from (at best) or somebody who demonstrates your failure (at worst).

tl,dr:  Deepfakes on surveillance video will emerge organically if we don’t recognize them as an obvious failure mode.  Moon mode is just the harmless expression of semantically meaningful noise, a risk underlying this entire space.

Data lies and wants you to be wrong.

1121689410540453888.text:
Truth is some people want to take a great photo of the moon and they’re walking away with exactly what they wanted, and that’s truly what the “unenhanced” photo would have contained. That “guess” was no risk, high reward.

We will have to learn to encode that.  That’s “all”.

1121689409022152704.text:
We are specifically not prepared for ML with semantically meaningful noise. We assume when a computer doesn’t know, it will lie poorly.

That is not necessarily the case. Moon mode works. If you think it’s cheating, ok, but its lie is very difficult to distinguish from truth.

1121689407428280320.text:
Computational photography and machine learning are lightning in a bottle, both some of the most transformative technologies I’ve played with, ever.

But you do need to know what the machine is telling you. Automated imagination is still but an informed guess.

1121689406140628993.text: And we become so sure, too sure that face is that person is that criminal is that prisoner to be. It was just an algorithm programmed to imagine the least wrong thing.  But we are pushing the logic further and further out.  We don’t always know what it’s sending back.

1121689404718768128.text:
A legitimate fear is when this process isn’t done just on features of a moon, but features of a face. Because we threw cameras everywhere thinking they would stop crime, and now we just see blurry blobs behaving badly.

Maybe someone hits Enhance. And now it’s a real face...

1121689402986516480.text:
This is all good, if you know what you’re mapping to what. “This mode, moon mode, shows you what the moon would look like if you had a tripod and long exposure, just with your shaky hand”

You can close your eyes and imagine. The code can match various constraints and synthesize.

1121689401145167873.text: A lot of actually working AI comes down to: “Here’s a bunch of noisy signal. Here’s ground truth. Find a system that turns this noise into that truth.” 30 photos from a shaky hand, one photo long exposure on a tripod. Learn to convert former into latter. We do this at scale now.

1121689399362633729.text: The field is having a moment because there is much more computational power available at time of initial capture. Forget reprocessing, now we just have initial processing.  We don’t merge 30 photos after the fact, we just take 30 and there’s your photo. Night vision.

1121689397433266176.text: There has long been this field of computational photography, that involves reprocessing of one or many possibly RAW datasets to develop better photos. I play in this space every so often — http://Fiji.sc  just gets better and more fun every year.

1121689395856232449.text: All photography involves filtering.  I mean, color involves selecting some photons and rejecting others. (Yeah. I know.)  All digital photography involves correcting for a miasma of factors. RAW isn’t just big because it’s uncompressed. There’s more data there, undisneyfied.

1121689394165866500.text:
Is this “cheating”?

It’s extraordinarily easy to say yes, of course it is, those aren’t the values that came off the Sony sensor, that’s just fitting a desired outcome over a noisy signal.

What’s interesting is how deep that rabbit hole goes.

1121689392311984128.text: So when you’re in moon mode, and you try to take a photo of the moon, it (supposedly — let’s assume this is true for the sake of this thread) combines incoming signal with the learned constraints of the moon to generate an accurate image without physical demands (tripods etc).

1121689387551485953.text:
Huawei’s P30 Pro probably has the best cell camera on the global market right now.  They’re doing magnificent work, with Sony sensors. Much respect.

There is literally concern about Huawei’s moon shots. Basically their AI has learned what the moon (mostly unchanging) looks like.
